sourceString: In a study conducted in Wuhan on 240 patients with pneumonia, half were given favipiravir and half received umifenovir.
targetString: Ha nder ekkitol feereha Wuhan ha do nyauɓe 240 be pneumonia, reeta maɓɓe hoosi favipiravir be reeta maɓɓe hoosi umifenovir.

sourceString: The Italian Pharmaceutical Agency reminded the public that the existing evidence in support of the drug is scant and preliminary.
targetString: Italian Pharmaceutical Agency matini ummatore yo'o sappinolji do wallende lekki ndu moftay tawon e jarfay.

sourceString: On 2 April, Germany announced that it would purchase the drug from Japan for its stockpile, and use the military to deliver the drug to university hospitals, where the drug will be used to treat COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Ha 2 Aviiril, Jaamani matini yo'o o soddan lekki ha Japan ngam ɗon mofti ha ton, soje'en ngam addugo lekki man ha suuɗi lekki jam'iareji, e lekki man wonan ngam hurgugo nyauɓe COVID-19.

sourceString: According to the South China Morning Post, Shinzo Abe has made overtures to the Trump administration about purchasing the drug.The drug may be less effective in severe cases of illness where the virus has already multiplied.
targetString: Ha South China Morning Post, Shinzo Abe arti ngomna Trump ngam soddugo lekki. Lekki footi wona maray sembe jur ha hurgol nyauɓe je nyau maɓɓe ɗon nyaɗi, e viriis man nufti timmi.

sourceString: It may not be safe for use by pregnant women or those trying to conceive.
targetString: Footi wonatta boɗɗu ha rewɓe be reedu hoosa ndu mala ɓe'en je yiɗi hoosugo reedu.

sourceString: One study of lopinavir/ritonavir (Kaletra), a combination of the antivirals lopinavir and ritonavir, concluded that "no benefit was observed".
targetString: Ekkitol feere do lopinavir/ritonavir (Kaletra), hawtirde lopinavir be ritonavir je ɗon mbarda viriis, wi'i yo'o "wala naffuda je tawama".

sourceString: The drugs were designed to inhibit HIV from replicating by binding to the protease.
targetString: Lekki ndi wurti ngam tuttugo HIV gal nuftugo gal hawtugo be protease.

sourceString: A team of researchers at the University of Colorado are trying to modify the drugs to find a compound that will bind with the protease of SARS-CoV-2.There are criticisms within the scientific community about directing resources to repurposing drugs specifically developed for HIV/AIDS.
targetString: Geeɓe teffooɓe ha University of Colorado yiɗi saanjugo lekki ngam heɓɓugo hawtirde je footi hawta be protease SARS-CoV. Wodi lasbinolji ha kunde ummatore teffooɓe ngam ɗowugo kujeji ngam laritugo lekki je wurtini ngam HIV/AIDS.

sourceString: The WHO included lopinavir/ritonavir in the international Solidarity trial.
targetString: WHO watti lopinavir/ritonavir ha nder foondol lesdi feere-feere Solidarity .

sourceString: Remdesivir was created and developed by Gilead Sciences as a treatment for Ebola virus disease and Marburg virus infections . Gilead Sciences subsequently discovered that Remdesivir had antiviral activity in vitro against multiple filo-, pneumo-, paramyxo-, and corona- viruses .
targetString: Remdesivir waɗɗotto e wurtinama gal Gilead Sciences bana hurgol nyau viriis Ebola be nyauji viriis Marburg. Gilead Sciences tawi fahin bo'o Remdesivir ɗon mari kuɗe je ɗon mbarda viriis in vitro do viriisji jur bana filo-, pneumo-, paramyxo-, be korona.

sourceString: One issue with antiviral treatment is the development of resistance through mutations that can lead to more severe disease and transmission.
targetString: Larula gooto ngam hurgol viriis woni neeɓugo gal saanjolji, ko footi yara ha nyau je ɓuri nyaɗugo be sallinol.

sourceString: Some early pretrial studies suggest remdesivir may have a high genetic barrier to resistance.There are several clinical trials underway, including two conducted by Cleveland University Hospitals; one for people with moderate illness and another for those with more severe illness.
targetString: Ekkitolji feere je fuɗɗi hiddeko foondol ɗon wi'a yo'o remdesivir footi mara keleewol gene ngam neeɓugo. Wodi foondolji ha suudu lekki je ɗon salla jonta, bana ɗiɗi je ɗon fadi gal Cleveland University Hospitals; gooto ngam yimɓe be nyau deydey be feere ngam ɓe'en je ɗon mari nyau je ɓuri nyaɗugo.

sourceString: There are three ongoing clinical trials of intravenous vitamin C for people who are hospitalized and severely ill with COVID-19; two placebo controlled (China, Canada) and one with no control (Italy).
targetString: Wodi foondolji ha suudu lekki tati je vitamin C je sallan nder lawol iyam ha yimɓe je ɗon wondi ha suudu lekki e ɗon mari COVID-19 je nyaɗungel; placebo je ɗon ayni ɗiɗi (Cayna, Kanada) be gooto je wala aynugo (Italy).

sourceString: New York State began trials for the antibiotic azithromycin on 24 March 2020.
targetString: New York State fuɗɗi foondolji ngam antibiotik azithromycin ha 24 Maars 2020.

sourceString: Japan's National Center for Global Health and Medicine (NCGM) is planning a clinical trial for Teijin's Alvesco (ciclesonide), an inhaled corticosteroid for asthma, for the treatment of pre-symptomatic patients infected with the novel coronavirus.
targetString: Japan's National Center for Global Health and Medicine (NCGM) ɗon waɗa jaahargal do foondolji ha suudu lekki ngam Teijin's Alvesco (ciclesonide), corticosteroid je mustugo ngam nyau dule, ngam hurgol nyauɓe je maray mandolji nyau tawon je raɓɓi koronaviriis keese.

sourceString: A form of angiotensin-converting enzyme 2, a Phase II trial is underway with 200 patients to be recruited from severe, hospitalized cases in Denmark, Germany, and Austria to determine the effectiveness of the treatment.
targetString: Irin angiotensin-converting enzyme 2, foondol Yaɓɓorde II ɗon do sallugo be nyauɓe 200 je ɓe suɓɓan no ha cakka ɓe'en je nyau man nyaɗi masin, wondi ha suudu lekki ha Denmark, Jaamani, be Ostriya ngam fammugo naffuda hurgol.

sourceString: Researchers from the Montreal Heart Institute in Canada are currently studying the role of colchicine in reducing inflammation and pulmonary complications in patients suffering from mild symptoms of COVID-19.
targetString: Teffooɓe ha Montreal Heart Institute ha Kanada ɗon jaanga kugal colchicine ngam ustugo huudure be nyaji fuffu ha nyauɓe je ɗon mari mandolji COVID-19 deydey.

sourceString: The study, named COLCORONA, is recruiting 6000 adults aged 40 and over who were diagnosed with COVID-19 and experience mild symptoms not requiring hospitalization.
targetString: Ekkitol, ewnotto COLCORONA, ɗon hoosa mauɓe 6000 je mari duɓɓi mala ɓuri je tawotto mari nyau COVID-19 e mari mandolji je maray haaje yahugo ha suudu lekki.

sourceString: Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding or who do not have an effective contraceptive method are not eligible.
targetString: Rewɓe je ɗon be reedu mala je ɗon musina mala mo je maray dabare siwtugo footay hoosa.

sourceString: Several anticoagulants are being tested in Italy.
targetString: Anticoagulantji jur ɗon do lartol ha Italy.

sourceString: Low-molecular-weight heparin is being widely used to treat patients, prompting the Italian Medicines Agency to publish guidelines on its use.
targetString: Heparin je ɗon mari molecule je ɗon lessi ɗon waagare nder hurgol nyauɓe, ko waɗi Italian Medecine Agency wurtina dabareji ngam huwugo be man.

sourceString: A multicenter study on 300 patients researching the use of enoxaparin sodium at prophylaxis and therapeutic dosages was announced in Italy on April 14.
targetString: Wakkere ekkitol feere do nyauɓe 300 je ɗon do teffugo kugal enoxaparin sodium ha prophylaxis be dabare hoosugo matinama ha italy ha 14 Aviiril.

sourceString: Since SARS-CoV-2 is a virus, considerable scientific attention has been focused on repurposing approved anti-viral drugs that were developed for prior outbreaks such as MERS, SARS, and West Nile virus.
targetString: Nde SARS-CoV-2 lati viriis, hakkika aandal wondi ngam laritugo lekki je mbardatta viriis je wangi hiddeko nyauji bana MERS, SARS, be viriis West Nile.

sourceString: Ribavirin: ribavirin was recommended for COVID-19 treatment according to Chinese 7th edition guidelines
targetString: Ribavirin: ribavirin feelama ngam hurgol COVID-19 bana limtol batakkewol sappinol 7 Cayna

sourceString: Umifenovir: umifenovir was recommended for COVID-19 treatment according to Chinese 7th edition guidelines
targetString: Umifenovir: umifenovir feelama ngam hurgol COVID-19 bana limtol batakkewol sappinol 7 Cayna

sourceString: Some antibiotics that have been identified as potentially repurposable as COVID-19 treatments:
targetString: Antibiotikji feere je ɗon maandi bana footi larita ndu bana dabare hurgol COVID-19:

sourceString: Tocilizumab (Anti-IL-6 receptor): Approved by China.
targetString: Tocilizumab (Anti-IL-6 receptor): Cayna jaɓɓi.

sourceString: Also trials in Italy and China. and see Tocilizumab#COVID-19.
targetString: Fahin bo'o foondolji ha Italy be Cayna. e lare Tocilizumab#COVID-19.

sourceString: b'A COVID-19 vaccine is a hypothetical vaccine against coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).
targetString: Baatal b'A COVID-19 lati bana baatal je aandakke boɗɗum ngam nyau koronaviriis 2019 (COVID-19).

sourceString: Although no vaccine has completed clinical trials, there are multiple attempts in progress to develop such a vaccine.
targetString: Ko to wala baatal je timmini foondolji ha suudu lekki, wodi dabareji feere-feere nder yahde ngam wurtinugo irin baatal ndu.

sourceString: In late February 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) said it did not expect a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2, the causative virus, to become available in less than 18 months.
targetString: Ha Feviriye 2020, Geeɓe Duniyaru do Jam Ɓaandu (WHO) wi'i o tammay baatal SARS-CoV-2, viriis je hokki nyau ndu, wonda hiddeko leebi 18.

sourceString: Five vaccine candidates were in Phase I safety studies in April.
targetString: Baatalji foondol joowey ɗon no do ekkitolji jam Yaɓɓorde I ha Aviiril.

sourceString: COVID-19 was identified in December 2019.
targetString: COVID-19 wangi ha Desambre 2020.

sourceString: A major outbreak spread around the world in 2020, leading to considerable investment and research activity to develop a vaccine.
targetString: Sankittol nyau man ha nder duniyaru salli ha 2020, je waɗi ceede jur nasti e aandooɓe ɗon teffa wurtinol baatal.

sourceString: Many organizations are using published genomes to develop possible vaccines against SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Geeɓeji jur ɗon huwida be genomeji ngam wurtinugo baatalji nyau SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: Stated in April, imperatives of the CEPI initiative for vaccine development are speed, manufacturing capacity, deployment at scale, and global access.
targetString: Wurti ha Aviiril, feeloji dabare CEPI ngam wanginugo baatal lati jaawal, dabare tagle, huwidugo ummatore jur, keɓɓal ko moy fu.

sourceString: In April, CEPI scientists reported that 10 different technology platforms were under research and development during early 2020 to create an effective vaccine against COVID-19.
targetString: Ha Aviril, aandooɓe CEPI matini daaldaji dabareji 10 ɗon no nder teffol be wanginnol ha fuɗɗam 2020 ngam wurtinugo baatal je ɗon naffa ngam COVID-19.

sourceString: Major platform targets advanced into Phase I safety studies include:
targetString: Daaldal kanduɗum ɗon nder ekkitolji jam Yaɓɓorde I je ɗon larni:

sourceString: nucleic acid (DNA and RNA) (Phase I developer and vaccine candidate: Moderna, mRNA-1273)
targetString: nucleic acid (DNA be RNA) (wanginoowo Yaɓɓorde I be baatal foondol: Moderna, mRNA-1273)

sourceString: viral vector (Phase I developer and vaccine candidate: CanSino Biologics, adenovirus type 5 vector)
targetString: viriis nyau (wanginowo Yaɓɓorde I be baatal foondol: CanSino Biologics, adenovirus type 5 vector)

sourceString: As reported by CEPI scientists in April, 115 total vaccine candidates are in early stages of development, with 78 confirmed as active projects (79, according to the Milken Institute), and 37 others announced, but with little public information available (presumed to be in planning or being designed).
targetString: Bana ɗon matini gal aandooɓe CEPI ha Aviiril, baatalji foondol hawti fu 115 ɗon do taskugo, be 78 lati bana kuɗe je ɗon yahida (79, ha sappinol Milken Institute), be 37 feere ɗon matini, amma be matinolji ummatore ɗon wondi (je nastan ha nder jaahargal mala ɗon suɓɓi).

sourceString: A Phase I-II trial conducts preliminary safety and immunogenicity testing, is typically randomized, placebo-controlled, and at multiple sites, while determining more precise, effective doses.
targetString: Foondol Yaɓɓorɗe I-II ɗon sallina arandere lartolji jam be immunogenecity, lati bana caacaa, aynotto be placebo, e ha wakkereji ɗuɗɗum, ha yakke maandugo hoosugo ndu be boɗɗe.

sourceString: Phase III trials typically involve more participants, including a control group, and test effectiveness of the vaccine to prevent the disease, while monitoring for adverse effects at the optimal dose.
targetString: Foondolji Yaɓɓorɗe III nastini ummatore jur, be geeɓe aynol, e larita naffuda baatal ngam aynugo nyau, e ngam aynugo sababuji je ɗon yahida be man.

sourceString: Of 79 vaccine candidates in active development (confirmed as of early April 2020), 74 were not yet in human evaluation (still in "preclinical" research).
targetString: Ha cakka baatal foondolji 79 do wurtinol (je ɗon aandin ha fuɗɗam Aviiril 2020), 74 nastay ha nder lartol neɗɗo tawon (ha jonta nder teffol "hiddeko suudu lekki").

sourceString: Around 24 January 2020 in Australia, the University of Queensland announced that it is investigating the potential of a molecular clamp vaccine that would genetically modify viral proteins in order to stimulate an immune reaction.
targetString: Gal 24 Zaanviye 2020 ha Australia, University of Queensland matini yo'o o ɗon no teffa molecule je footi wangina baatal je footi saanja proteinji viriis ndu ngam heɓɓa ɓaandu noota.

sourceString: Around 24 January 2020 in Canada, the International Vaccine Centre (VIDO-InterVac) at the University of Saskatchewan announced the commencement of work on a vaccine, aiming to start human testing in 2021.
targetString: Gal 24 Zaanviye 2020 ha Kanada, International Vaccine Centre (VIDO-InterVac) ha University Saskatchewan matini yo'o fuɗɗam kugal do baatal, je yiɗi sallinugo foondol do neɗɗo ha 2021.

sourceString: Vaccine development projects were announced at the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention on 26 January 2020, and the University of Hong Kong on 28 January.
targetString: Kuɗe wurtinugo baatal matinama ha Ɗowirɗe Aynol e Lartol Nyau Cayna ha 26 Zaanviye 2020, e University of Hong Kong ha 28 Zaanviye.

sourceString: Around 29 January 2020, Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies, led by Hanneke Schuitemaker, announced that it had begun work on developing a vaccine.
targetString: Gal 29 Zaanviye 2020, Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies, je Hanneke Schuitemaker lati arduɗo majuum, wi'i o fuɗɗi huwidugo do baatal ngu.

sourceString: Janssen is co-developing an oral vaccine with its biotechnology partner, Vaxart.
targetString: Janssen ɗon huwida do baatal gal hunduko be bero mako, Vaxart.

sourceString: On 18 March 2020, Emergent BioSolutions announced a manufacturing partnership with Vaxart to develop the vaccine.
targetString: Ha 18 Maars, Emmergent BioSolution matini huwidugo be Vaxart ngam wurtinugo baatal.

sourceString: On 8 February 2020, the laboratory OncoGen in Romania published a paper on the design of a vaccine with similar technology to the one used for cancer neoantigen vaccination therapy.
targetString: Ha 8 Feviriye 2020, suudu lartol OncoGen in Romania wurtini batakkewol feere do dabare wurtinugo baatal be irin teknik je baatal neoantigen hurgol sankara.

sourceString: On 25 March the head of the research institute announced that they had finalized the synthesis of the vaccine and were beginning the tests.
targetString: Ha 25 Maars ɗowuwo geeɓe teffol matini yo'o ɓe timmini lartol baatal e fuɗɗi be lartolji timmi.

sourceString: On 27 February 2020, a Generex subsidiary company, NuGenerex Immuno-Oncology, announced they were beginning a vaccine project to create an Ii-Key peptide vaccine against COVID-19.
targetString: Ha 27 Feviriye 2020, Generex subsidiary company, NuGenerex Immuno-Oncology, matini yo'o ɓe ɗon fuɗɗa kuɗe do teffol baatal ngam wanginugo baatal li-Key peptide ngam nyau COVID-19.

sourceString: They wanted to produce a vaccine candidate that could be tested in humans "within 90 days."
targetString: Ɓe yiɗi wurtinugo baatal foondol je footi en larta do yimɓe "ha nder balɗe 90".

sourceString: On 5 March 2020, Washington University in St. Louis announced its projects to develop a vaccine.
targetString: Ha 5 Maars 2020, Washington University in St. Louis matini kuɗe mako ngam wurtinugo baatal.

sourceString: On 5 March 2020, the United States Army Medical Research and Materiel Command at Fort Detrick and the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research in Silver Spring, both in western Maryland, announced they were working on a vaccine.
targetString: Ha nyalade 5 lewru maars, Arduɗo Geebe Teffol Soje Jam Bandu Lesɗi America ha Fort Detrick be Suudu Jaangirde Teffol Soje Walter Reed ha Silver Spring, ɗiɗi fu ha Marvland je hirnaange, matini yo'o ɓe ɗon huwa ngam wurtinugo baatal.

sourceString: Around 10 March 2020, Emergent Biosolutions announced that it had teamed with Novavax Inc.
targetString: Gal 10 Maars 2020, Emergent Biosolutions matini huwidugo be Novavax Inc.

sourceString: in the development and manufacture of a vaccine.
targetString: ngam dabare wanginugo e wurtinugo baatal.

sourceString: The partners further announced plans for preclinical testing and a Phase I clinical trial by July 2020.
targetString: Bero'en mako matini yo'o jaahargal lartol hiddeko suddu lekki be foondol Yaɓɓorde I ha suudu lekki gal Zwiiye 2020.

sourceString: On 12 March 2020, India's Health Ministry announced they are working with 11 isolates, and that even on a fast track it would take at least around one-and-a-half to two years to develop a vaccine.
targetString: Ha 12 Maars 2020, Geeɓe jam ɓaandu India matini yo'o ɓe ɗon huwa be baatalji 11, e ko to yaawi ma footi neeɓa duɓɓi be reeta mala duɓɓi ɗiɗi ngam wurtinugo baatal.

sourceString: On 12 March 2020, Medicago, a biotechnology company in Quebec City, Quebec, reported development of a coronavirus-like particle under partial funding from the Canadian Institutes for Health Research.
targetString: Ha 12 Maars 2020, Medicago, biotechnology company ha Quebec City, Quebec, matini kugal do wurtinugo kuje feere je ɗon naandi koronaviriis je Canadian Institutes for Health Research hokki ceede seeɗa.

sourceString: The vaccine candidate is in laboratory research, with human testing planned for July or August 2020.
targetString: Baatal foondol ɗon ha nder suudu teffol, be lartolji do yimɓe ɗon hasdi ngam Zwiiye mala Uut 2020.

sourceString: Earlier that week, The Guardian reported that the US President Donald Trump had offered CureVac "'large sums of money' for exclusive access to a Covid-19 vaccine", against which the German government protested.
targetString: Ha fuɗɗam asawere ndu, The Guardian matini yo'o Jagorɗo Lesɗe America Donald Trump hokki ha CureVac "ceede ɗuɗɗum ngam wurtinugo baatal COVID-19", je ngomna Jaamani yarday sam.

sourceString: On 17 March 2020, American pharmaceutical company Pfizer announced a partnership with German company BioNTech to jointly develop a mRNA-based vaccine.
targetString: Ha 17 Maars 2020, American pharmaceutical company Pfizer matini huwidugo be German company BioNTech ngam wurtinugo baatal mRNA.

sourceString: mRNA-based vaccine candidate BNT162, currently in pre-clinical testing with clinical trials expected to begin in April 2020.
targetString: Baatal foondol mRNA BNT162, jonta ha nder lartol hidekko suddu lekki be foondolji je hasdi wurtugo ha fuɗɗam Aviiril 2020.

sourceString: In Italy on 17 March 2020, Takis Biotech, an Italian biotech company announced they will have pre-clinical testing results in April 2020 and their final vaccine candidate could begin human testing by fall.
targetString: Ha Italy ha 17 Maars 2020, Takis Biotech, biotech company Italy matini yo'o ɓe maran sappinolji lartol hiddeko suudu lekki ha Aviiril 2020 e baatal foondol je ragare footi fuɗɗa hiddeko timminol hittande nde.

sourceString: In France on 19 March 2020, the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) announced a US$4.9 million investment in a COVID-19 vaccine research consortium involving the Institut Pasteur, Themis Bioscience (Vienna, Austria), and the University of Pittsburgh, bringing CEPI's total investment in COVID-19 vaccine development to US$29 million.
targetString: Ha Faransa ha 19 Maars 2020, Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) matini wurtinugo milionji US$4.9 ngam teffol do baatal COVID-19 be geeɓe bana Institut Pasteur, Themis Bioscience (Vienna, Austria), be University of Pittsburgh, ko ɗon hawti moftol ceede CEPI ngam wanginugo baatal COVID-19 ha milionji US$29.

sourceString: CEPI's other investment partners for COVID-19 vaccine development are Moderna, Curevac, Inovio, Novavax, the University of Hong Kong, the University of Oxford, and the University of Queensland.
targetString: Geeji feere je CEPI ɗon huwida be maɓɓe ngam wurtinol baatal nyau COVID-19 lati Moderna, Curevac, Inovio, Novavax, University of Hong Kong, University of Oxford, be University of Queensland.

sourceString: On 20 March 2020, Russian health officials announced that scientists have begun animal testing of six different vaccine candidates.
targetString: Ha 20 Maars 2020, yimɓe ngomna Russiya matini yo'o aandooɓe fuɗɗi lartolji do daabaji be baatalji foondol joowey go'o.

sourceString: Imperial College London researchers announced on 20 March 2020 that they are developing a self-amplifying RNA vaccine for COVID-19.
targetString: Teffooɓe Imperial College London researchers matini ha 20 Maars 2020 yo'o ɓe ɗn no waɗa dabare wurtinugo baatal NRA je ɗon yajja feere maɗa ngam COVID-19.

sourceString: The vaccine candidate was developed within 14 days of receiving the sequence from China.
targetString: Ko footi wona baatal ndu huwidotto ha nder balɗe 14 diga jaɓɓugo kuje man ha Cayna.

sourceString: In late March, the Canadian government announced C$275 million in funding for 96 research projects on medical countermeasures against COVID-19, including numerous vaccine candidates at Canadian companies and universities, such as the Medicago and University of Saskatchewan initiatives.
targetString: Ha ragare Maars, ngomna Kanada matini wurtinugo milionji C$275 bana wallende kuɗe teffol 96 ngam dabareji jam ɓaandu ngam COVID-19, be baatalji foondol jur ha nder geeɓeji be jam'iareji Kanadiya'en bana dabareji Medicago and University of Saskatchewan.

sourceString: Around the same time, the Canadian government announced C$192 million specifically for developing a COVID-19 vaccine, with plans to establish a national "vaccine bank" of several new vaccines that could be used if another coronavirus outbreak occurs.
targetString: Ha wakati ndu, ngomna Kanada matini wurtinugo milionji C$192 ngam wanginugo baatal COVID-19, be jaahargalji mahugo "siggorde baatalji" ngam baatalji keese ɗuɗɗum je footi naffa to nyau koronaviriis feere wangi.

sourceString: On 2 April 2020, researchers at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine reported on testing of PittCoVacc, a possible COVID-19 vaccine in mice, stating that "MNA delivered SARS-CoV-2 S1 subunit vaccines elicited potent antigen-specific antibody responses [in the mice] that were evident beginning 2 weeks after immunization."
targetString: Ha 2 Aviiril 2020, teffooɓe ha University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine matini ngam lartugo PittCoVacc, baatal COVID-19 ha doomɓi, gal wi'ugo yo'o "MNA wurtini geeɓe baatalji SARS-CoV-2 S1 je ɗon tutta fadooɓe ɓaandu je ɗon mari antigene je ɗon mari semɓe [ha nder doomɓi] je fuɗɗan asaweji 2 ha ɓawo fadol."

sourceString: In Canada on 16 April 2020, the University of Waterloo School of Pharmacy announced design of a DNA-based vaccine candidate as a possible nasal spray.
targetString: Ha Kanada ha 16 Aviril 2020, Jam'iare Waterloo School of Pharmacy matini sappinol DNA ko footi wona baatal je lati bana lekki fuffugo ha nder kine.

sourceString: Using bacteriophages, the DNA will be designed to replicate inside human bacteria to produce harmless virus-like particles, which may stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
targetString: Huwugo be bacteriophageji, DNA naffan ngam nuftugo ha nder bakteriyaji neɗɗo ngam wurtinugo coolaaje je naandi viriis je wala nyaɗugo, je footi sembintina dabare fadol ɓaandu ngam wurtinugo fadooɓe ɓaandu ngam viriis SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: In March 2020, the US government, industry, and three universities pooled resources to access supercomputers from IBM, combined with cloud computing resources from Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Amazon, Microsoft, and Google.
targetString: Ha Maars 2020, ngomna Lesɗe America, suudu tagle, be jam'iareji hawti sembe maɓɓe ngam nastugo ha nder ordoji nyaɗum gal IBM, hawti be dabareji huwidol do hawo Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Amazon, Microsoft, be Google.

sourceString: Some vaccines have heterologous effects, also called non-specific effects.
targetString: Baatalji feere ɗon mari sababuji feere, e ewnotto bo'o sababuji je ɗon saanja.

sourceString: That means they can have benefits beyond the disease they prevent.
targetString: Bana wi'ugo ɓe footi mara ribaji ha gaɗɗa nyau je ɗon ayna.

sourceString: A further randomized trial in Australia is seeking to enrol 4,170 healthcare workers.
targetString: Foondol feere ha Australia ɗon teffa nastinugo huwooɓe jam ɓaandu 4170.

sourceString: It is possible vaccines in development will not be safe or effective.
targetString: Footi bo'o baatalji je do wurtugo footi wonatta jam mala mara naffuda.

sourceString: Early research to assess vaccine efficacy using COVID-19-specific animal models, such as ACE2-transgenic mice, other laboratory animals, and non-human primates, indicate a need for biosafety-level 3 containment measures for handling live viruses, and international coordination to ensure standardized safety procedures.
targetString: Teffolji arandere ngam lartugo naffitirki baatal gal hoosugo irin COVID-19 je yahidan be daabaji bana doombi ACE2-transgenic., daabaji suudu lartolji feere, be wandu'en je nastay nder asngol neɗɗo, sappina haaje ngam dabareji darnugo biosafety-level 3 ngam memmugo viriisji je ɗon nyeeɗa, be fadol duniyaru ngam hollugo dabareji jam je ɗon aandi.

sourceString: Vaccines against SARS and MERS have been tested in non-human animal models.
targetString: Baatalji ngam SARS be MERS lartama ha nder naandolji je wonay goɗɗo.

sourceString: As of 2020, there is no cure or protective vaccine for SARS that has been shown to be both safe and effective in humans.
targetString: Ha 2020, wala hurgol mala baatal aynugo ngam SARS je sappinama ɗon jam e naffan neɗɗo.

sourceString: According to research papers published in 2005 and 2006, the identification and development of novel vaccines and medicines to treat SARS was a priority for governments and public health agencies around the world.There is also no proven vaccine against MERS.
targetString: Bana sappinol batakkeji teffoln2005 be 2006, maandirɗum be wanginol baataji keese be lekki hurgol SARS lati aranool nummol ngomna'en be geeɓeji jam ɓaandu ummatore ha nder lesdi. Fahin, wala baatal je ɗon aandin ngam MERS.

sourceString: When MERS became prevalent, it was believed that existing SARS research may provide a useful template for developing vaccines and therapeutics against a MERS-CoV infection.
targetString: Ha wakati je MERS wangi, yimɓe tammi yo'o teffolji do SARS footi dabare feere ngam wurtinugo baatalji mala lekki nyau MERS-CoV.

sourceString: As of March 2020, there was one (DNA based) MERS vaccine which completed phase I clinical trials in humans, and three others in progress, all of which are viral-vectored vaccines, two adenoviral-vectored (ChAdOx1-MERS,  BVRS-GamVac), and one MVA-vectored (MVA-MERS-S).
targetString: Ha 20 Maars 2020, wodi no baatal MERS (je wondi do DNA) je timmini foondolji yaɓɓorde I ha suudu lekki, be feere en tati, je fu woni baatalji viriis, adenoviriis,  (ChAdOx1-MERS,  BVRS-GamVac), be  MVA-vectored (MVA-MERS-S) woore.

sourceString: Social media posts have promoted a conspiracy theory claiming the virus behind COVID-19 was known and that a vaccine was already available.
targetString: Sappinolji bindi ha hubaru ummatore wurtini ngewte dabare gal wi'ugo viriis je ɗon wondi ha ɓawo COVID-19 ɗon no aandi e baatal man ɗon timmi.

sourceString: The patents cited by various social media posts reference existing patents for genetic sequences and vaccines for other strains of coronavirus such as the SARS coronavirus.
targetString: Aandinolji je ɗon limti ha do daaldal ummatore ɗon lorta ha aandinolji je ɗon no wondi aran ngam ta'irde geneji ngam asli coronaviriis feere bana koronaviriis SARS.

sourceString: b'Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is an infectious disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
targetString: Nyau koronaviriis b' 2019 (COVID-19) lati nyau je ɗon raɓɓa be saɗirma nder pofɗe je wangi gal koronaviiris 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

sourceString: Common symptoms include fever, cough, and shortness of breath.
targetString: Mandolji je ɓurna larni wullol ɓaandu, sondaru, be pofɗe bana daran.

sourceString: Other symptoms may include fatigue, muscle pain, diarrhea, sore throat, loss of smell, and abdominal pain.
targetString: Mandolji feere footi larni tampere, nawne ɓaandu, caarol, daande be huudure, majjinol haccenga, nawne reedu.

sourceString: The time from exposure to onset of symptoms is typically around five days but may range from two to fourteen days.
targetString: Wakati diga raɓɓol ha fuɗɗam mandolji ɗon gal balɗe joowey amma footi yaha diga balɗe ɗiɗi ha sappo e nay.

sourceString: While the majority of cases result in mild symptoms, some progress to viral pneumonia and multi-organ failure.
targetString: Nyauɓe ɓurna fu ɗon mari mandolji je nyaɗay, amma feere footi yotta ha pneumonia be nyau kujeji reedu feere-feere.

sourceString: As of 17 April 2020, more than 2.24 million cases have been reported across 210 countries and territories, resulting in more than 153,000 deaths.
targetString: Ha 17 Aviiril 2020, ɓuri nyauɓe milionji 2.24 matinama bana mari nyau ha nder lesɗe be wakkereji 210, be ɓuri yimɓe 153 000 maynama.

sourceString: More than 568,000 people have recovered.The virus is primarily spread between people during close contact, often via small droplets produced by coughing, sneezing, or talking.
targetString: Yimɓe ɓuri 568 000 nyamɓitti. Viriis sankitti ha kunde ummatore ha aranool man  gal wondidugo, ɓurna fu gal tuɗe je ɗon toɓa ha yakke sondaru, ɓislol, mala ngewte.

sourceString: While these droplets are produced when breathing out, they usually fall to the ground or onto surfaces rather than being infectious over long distances.
targetString: Ha yakke je tuɗe ɗon toɓa ha wakati fuffugo, ɗon do'a ha lesdi mala ha do daaldal na hoorama ngam raɓɓugo yimɓe gal hendu.

sourceString: People may also become infected by touching a contaminated surface and then touching their eyes, nose, or mouth.
targetString: Yimɓe footi nanga nyau gal memmugo baabe je ɗon raɓɓi e ha ɓawo man memma gite gite, kine mala hunduko maɓɓe.

sourceString: The virus can survive on surfaces up to 72 hours.
targetString: Viriis ndu footi yeeɗa do daldal ha njamdi 72.

sourceString: It is most contagious during the first three days after the onset of symptoms, although spread may be possible before symptoms appear and in later stages of the disease.The standard method of diagnosis is by real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) from a nasopharyngeal swab.
targetString: Nyau ndu ɓuri raɓɓugo ha arandere balɗe tati diga fuɗɗorde nyau ndu, ko to sankittol footi wona hiddeko wangol mandolji be gal ragare nyau ndu. Dabare lartol je yimɓe ɓuri  aandugo woni jaangirde polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) gal ɓawo gal illam kine mala daande.

sourceString: The use of masks is recommended for those who suspect they have the virus and their caregivers.
targetString: Wondugo be leepolji suddugo yeeso ɗon feeli ha yimɓe je tammi marugo viriis be ɓe'en je suklata do maɓɓe.

sourceString: Recommendations for mask use by the general public vary, with some authorities recommending against their use, some recommending their use, and others requiring their use.
targetString: Wondugo be leepol suddugo yeeso gal ummatore ɗon saanja, be arduɓe feere je yarday yimɓe ɓorna ɗum, feere'en bo'o ɗon feela ɓornugo ɗum, e feere bo'o ɗon dula ɓornugo ndu.

sourceString: Currently, there is no vaccine or specific antiviral treatment for COVID-19.
targetString: Ha jonta, walla baatal mala lekki hurgol viriis je ɗon aandi ngam COVID-19.

sourceString: Local transmission of the disease has been recorded in most countries across all six WHO regions.
targetString: Sallinol nyau ha cakka ummatore ɗon matinama he ɓurna lesɗe fu nder wakkereji WHO.

sourceString: Those infected with the virus may be asymptomatic or develop flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, fatigue, and shortness of breath.
targetString: Yimɓe je viriis raɓɓi ɓe footi marata mandolji nyau mala sappina mandolji bana je ndamba bana wullol baandu, sondaru, tampere, be pofɗe bana daran.

sourceString: Emergency symptoms include difficulty breathing, persistent chest pain or pressure, confusion, difficulty waking, and bluish face or lips; immediate medical attention is advised if these symptoms are present.
targetString: Mandolji fuɗɗam larni saɗirma pofɗe, nawol mala harlol ɓernde je ɗon neeɓa, harbol, saɗirma be finnugo, saanjol yeeso be hunduko; to mandolji ndu wangi sey a ɓadita yimɓe jam ɓaandu.

sourceString: Less commonly, upper respiratory symptoms such as sneezing, runny nose or sore throat may be seen.
targetString: Ha yakke feere, mandolji pofɗe do bana ɓislugo, illol kine mala daande be huudure footi wona.

sourceString: Gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea have been observed in varying percentages.
targetString: Mandolji reedu mala teeteki bana tutta, tuttol be caarol woni be limtol je ɗon saanja tum.

sourceString: Some cases in China initially presented only with chest tightness and palpitations.
targetString: Nyauɓe feere ha Cayna sappini ha arandere harlol ɓernde be duwinol ɓernde.

sourceString: In some, the disease may progress to pneumonia, multi-organ failure, and death.
targetString: Ha feere'en, nyau man footi waylitta do pneumonia, saɗirma kujeji reedu jur be wade.

sourceString: This is called the incubation period.
targetString: Ndu ewnotto wakati nuftol.

sourceString: The incubation period for COVID-19 is typically five to six days but may range from two to 14 days.
targetString: Wakati nuftol COVID-19 woni balɗe joowey ha joowey go'o amma footi wona ha kunde balɗe ɗiɗi ha 14.

sourceString: 97.5% of people who develop symptoms will do so within 11.5 days of infection.Reports indicate that not all who are infected develop symptoms.
targetString: 97.5% yimɓe je sappini mandolji waɗan bana ni ha nder balɗe 11.5 nyau ndu. Batakkeji hubaruji ɗon sappina yo'o na kala moy fu je mari nyau on sappinatta mandolji ndu.

sourceString: The role of these asymptomatic carriers in transmission is not yet fully known; however, preliminary evidence suggests that they may contribute to the spread of the disease.
targetString: Kugal irin roondooɓe ha nder sallinol aandake boɗɗum tawon; amma, arandere sappinolji ɗon holla yo'o footi ɓe naffa nder sankittugo nyau ndu.

sourceString: The proportion of infected people who do not display symptoms is currently unknown and being studied, with the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (KCDC) reporting that 20% of all confirmed cases remained asymptomatic during their hospital stay.
targetString: Ta'irde yimɓe je ɗon mari gilɗi ndu amma sappinata mandolji nyau ngu aandake e lati lartotto haande, ngam Ɗowirdeji Aynol be Fadol Nyau (KCDC) wi'i yo'o 20 nder 100 sappinay mandolji ha wakati jonde maɓɓe ha suudu lekki.

sourceString: China's National Health Commission began including asymptomatic cases in its daily cases on 1 April; of the 166 infections on that day, 130 (78%) were asymptomatic at the time of testing.
targetString: China's National Health Commission fuɗɗi nastinugo nyauɓe je sappinata mandolji nyau ha nder nyauɓe balɗe ha 1 Aviiril; ha cakka nyauɓe 166 ha nder balɗe nde, 130 (78%) sappinatta no mandolji nyau ha wakati lartol.

sourceString: Both sputum and saliva can carry large viral loads.
targetString: Didi fu tuutol be tuuɗe footi ronda gildi duɗɗum.

sourceString: Loud talking releases more droplets than normal talking.
targetString: Wolwugo be sembe ɗon toɓina tuɗe jur do wolwugo be leesare.

sourceString: A study in Singapore found that an uncovered cough can lead to droplets travelling up to 4.5 meters (15 feet).
targetString: Ekkitol feere ha Singapore tawi yo'o sondaru je sudday footi waɗa tuɗe do'a e footi yaha metaaji 4.5 (kosɗe).

sourceString: Though the virus is not generally airborne, the National Academy of Science has suggested that bioaerosol transmission may be possible and air collectors positioned in the hallway outside of people's rooms yielded samples positive for viral RNA.
targetString: Ko to viriis hortakke gal hendu, National Academy of Science holli yo'o sallinol gal hendu footi waɗa, e hoccooɓe hendu je ɗon jo'ini ha dammuɗe jawleruji ɗon no roondi lekkuji je ɗon mari viris RNA.

sourceString: Some medical procedures such as intubation and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) may cause respiratory secretions to be aerosolised and thus result in airborne spread.
targetString: Laahalji jam ɓaandu feere bana nastinugo kuje gal daande be ummitinugo ɓernde be fuffu (CPR) footi wangina illam pofɗe je footi wurta be pofɗe e bana ni hendu sankitta ndu.

sourceString: While there are concerns it may spread via feces, this risk is believed to be low.The virus is most contagious when people are symptomatic; while spread may be possible before symptoms emerge, the risk is low.
targetString: Ha yakke je wodi larulaji ngam fammugo to footi salla gal buuwe, sababu ndu tammi lessi; ha yakke je sankittol footi salla hiddeko mandolji wanga, sababu ndu lessi.

sourceString: The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) says while it is not entirely clear how easily the disease spreads, one person generally infects two to three others.The virus survives for hours to days on surfaces.
targetString: Ɗowirɗe Aynol be Lartol Nyau (ECDC) wi'i ko to wanay laɓɗe fammugo noy nyau man footi sankitta be kooyɗum, goɗɗo gooto footi raɓɓa yimɓe ɗiɗi mala tati. Viriis footi nyeeɗa do daaldalji nder njamɗe ha balɗe.

sourceString: Specifically, the virus was found to be detectable for one day on cardboard, for up to three days on plastic (polypropylene) and stainless steel (AISI 304), and for up to four hours on 99% copper.
targetString: Viriis ndu tawama bana footi maanda ɗum nder balɗe woore ha do takkarde, ngam ha balɗe tati do leeda (polypylene) be nyama larta (AISI 304), e ha njamɗe do 99% cardi.

sourceString: This, however, varies depending on the humidity and temperature.
targetString: Amma, ndu ɗon saanja be peewol be gulɗam.

sourceString: Soap and detergent are also effective if correctly used; soap products degrade the virus' fatty protective layer, deactivating it, as well as freeing them from skin and other surfaces.
targetString: Sabulu be omo ɗon naffa bo'o to hocci be lawol man; kujeji sabulu ɗon ɓoora ɓeelere je ɗon tardi gilɗi ndu, itta ɗum, e willa ɓe do ɓaandu be daaldalji feere.

sourceString: Other solutions, such as benzalkonium chloride and chlorhexidine gluconate (a surgical disinfectant), are less effective.In a Hong Kong study, saliva samples were taken a median of two days after the start of hospitalization.
targetString: Dabareji feere bana benzalkonium chloride be chlorhexidine gluconate (kuje laɓɓinugo seekkowo), maray sembe jur. Ekkitol feere ha Hong Kong, leeku tuɗe ɗon no hoosa ɓurna balɗe ɗiɗi ha ɓawo fuɗɗam wondugo ha suudu lekki.

sourceString: In five of six patients, the first sample showed the highest viral load, and the sixth patient showed the highest viral load on the second day tested.
targetString: Ha nder cakka nyauɓe nay do joowey, aranool leeku sappini limtol viriis je ɓuri fu, be joowey e woore nyauɗo sappini limtol viriisji je ɓuri ha ɗiɗaɓre balɗe lartol.

sourceString: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is a novel severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus, first isolated from three people with pneumonia connected to the cluster of acute respiratory illness cases in Wuhan.
targetString: Koronaviriis 2 (SARS-CoV-2) je ɗon hokka nyau saɗirma pofɗe woni koronaviriis keese be je saɗirma pofɗe, tawama arandere ha yimɓe tati be pneumonia je hawti be sammere nyau pofɗe ha Wuhan.

sourceString: All features of the novel SARS-CoV-2 virus occur in related coronaviruses in nature.
targetString: Mandolji viriis SARS-CoV keese ɗon salla bana je koronaviriis.

sourceString: Outside the human body, the virus is killed by household soap, which bursts its protective bubble.SARS-CoV-2 is closely related to the original SARS-CoV.
targetString: Ha yaasi ɓaandu neɗɗo, sabulu saare ɗon mbarda viriis man, je ɗon feetina nguffu je ɗon fadi mo. SARS-CoV-2 ɗon naandi be arandere SARS-CoV.

sourceString: The lungs are the organs most affected by COVID-19 because the virus accesses host cells via the enzyme angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), which is most abundant in the type II alveolar cells of the lungs.
targetString: Fuffu lati ko je COVID-19 ɗon memma jur ngam viriis ɗon nasta cellji jaɓɓoowo gal neebam angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), je ɓuri wondugo ha type II alveolar cellji fuffu.

sourceString: The virus uses a special surface glycoprotein called a "spike" (peplomer) to connect to ACE2 and enter the host cell.
targetString: Viriis ndu ɗon hoosa daaldal glycoprotein feerejo ewnotto "hoore" (peplomer) ngam hawtugo be ACE2 e nastugo nder cell jaɓɓowo.

sourceString: Acute cardiac injury was found in 12% of infected people admitted in hospital in Wuhan, China, and is more frequent in severe disease.
targetString: Huudure seeɗa do ɓernde tawama ha 12% yimɓe je mari nyau e je wondi ha suudu lekki ha Wuhan, Cayna, e ɗon woni ɓurna fu ha nder nyau ndu.

sourceString: Rates of cardiovascular symptoms is high, owing to the systemic inflammatory response and immune system disorders during disease progression, but acute myocardial injury may also be related to ACE2 receptors in the heart.
targetString: Limtolji mandolji nyau ɓernde ɗon wa'i, ngam jabbuye do dabare hurgugo huudure be fadol ha wakati yahde nyau, amma huudure myokard footi bo'o larna jaɓɓoowo ACE2 ha nder ɓernde.

sourceString: ACE2 receptors are highly expressed in the heart and are involved in heart function.
targetString: Jaɓɓoowo ACE2 ɗon sappini ha nder ɓernde e ɗon naffa nder kugal ɓernde.

sourceString: A high incidence of thrombosis (31%) and venous thromboembolism (25%) have been found in ICU patients with COVID-19 infections and may be related to poor prognosis.Autopsies of people who died of COVID-19 have found diffuse alveolar damage (DAD), and lymphocyte-containing inflammatory infiltrates within the lung.
targetString: Be tawi yo'o wodi kuje feere ɗon fuɗa ha nder iyam maɓɓe (31%) e ko mbiyotto thromboembolism (25%) tawama ha nyauɓe ICU je ɗon mari nyau COVID-19 e footi en yecca yahay. Lartol ɓaandu nyauɓe COVID-19 je maynama sappini nawnol fuffu  (DAD), e ndiyam iyam je ɗon mari ko nyauwata ndu ɗon no illa nder fuffu.

sourceString: Although SARS-COV-2 has a tropism for ACE2-expressing epithelial cells of the respiratory tract, patients with severe COVID-19 have symptoms of systemic hyperinflammation.
targetString: Ko to SARS-COV-2 ɗon mari tropism ngam ACE2-expressing epithelial cellji lawol pofɗe, nyauɓe be COVID-19 je nyaɗi ɗon mari mandolji yajjugo huudure ndu.

sourceString: In particular, pathogenic GM-CSF-secreting T-cells were shown to correlate with the recruitment of inflammatory IL-6-secreting monocytes and severe lung pathology in COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Ba wi'ugo, pathogenic GM-CSF-je ɗon ruffa T-cellji bana ɗon yahida be nastirde inflammatory IL-6-je ɗon fuffa monocyteji be mandolji fuffu je nyaɗum ha nyauɓe COVID-19.

sourceString: Lymphocytic infiltrates have also been reported at autopsy.
targetString: Illol lymphocyt ha toon bo'o matinama ha nder mayde.

sourceString: The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease.
targetString: WHO wangini dabareji lartol nyau ndu.

sourceString: The standard method of testing is real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR).
targetString: Dabare lartol je ɗon aandi woni real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR).

sourceString: The test is typically done on respiratory samples obtained by a nasopharyngeal swab; however, a nasal swab or sputum sample may also be used.
targetString: Lartol ndu ngaɗama ɓurna fu be leeku pofɗe je ɓe ɗon hoosa gal illam kine mala je daande; amma, footi bo'o hoosa leeku ndamba mala illam kine.

sourceString: Results are generally available within a few hours to two days.
targetString: Sappinolji ɓurna fu ɗon wanga ha nder njamɗe seeɗa mala balɗe ɗiɗi.

sourceString: Blood tests can be used, but these require two blood samples taken two weeks apart and the results have little immediate value.
targetString: Lartolji iyam footi naffa, amma kanjuum yiɗi sey hoosa leekuji ɗiɗi je hoccama asaweji ɗiɗi be sappinolji ndu je wangata law.

sourceString: Chinese scientists were able to isolate a strain of the coronavirus and publish the genetic sequence so laboratories across the world could independently develop polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests to detect infection by the virus.
targetString: Teffooɓe Cayna footi no wurtinugo asli koronaviriis feere e sappini ta'irde gene heɓɓa cuuɗi lartol ha nder duniyaru footi wangina lartolji polymerase chain reaction (PCR) ngam maandugo nyau viriis ndu.

sourceString: As of 4 April 2020, antibody tests (which may detect active infections and whether a person had been infected in the past) were in development, but not yet widely used.
targetString: Ha Aviiril 2020, lartolji fadooɓe ɓaandu (je footi maanda nyauji e to goɗɗo nangi no nyau ara) ɗon no do yahde, amma je na yimɓe fu on huwatta be man tawon.

sourceString: The Chinese experience with testing has shown the accuracy is only 60 to 70%.
targetString: Ekkitol yimɓe Cayna be lartol sappini yo'o goonakku maɗa woni 60 ha 70% tan.

sourceString: The FDA in the United States approved the first point-of-care test on 21 March 2020 for use at the end of that month.Diagnostic guidelines released by Zhongnan Hospital of Wuhan University suggested methods for detecting infections based upon clinical features and epidemiological risk.
targetString: FDA ha Lesɗe America yardi aranol lartol ha wakkere jam ɓaandu ha 21 Maars 2020 ngam huwugo be man ha ragare lewru. Dabare lartol je waangi gal Zhongnan Hospital Wuhan University feeli laahalji maandugo nyauji gal mandolji nyau be sababu nyau.

sourceString: Bilateral multilobar ground-glass opacities with a peripheral, asymmetric and posterior distribution are common in early infection.
targetString: Bilateral multilobar ground-glass opacities be sallinol yaasi, je yahiday be ɓawo tawama ɓurna fu ha nder aranool nyau.

sourceString: Subpleural dominance, crazy paving (lobular septal thickening with variable alveolar filling), and consolidation may appear as the disease progresses.
targetString: Subpleural dominance, crazy paving (uppugo lobular septal be illol je ɗon saanja ha nder alveolji), be sattugo footi wona to bana nyau ndu ɗon yahda.

sourceString: Few data are available about microscopic lesions and the pathophysiology of COVID-19.
targetString: Wala matinolji ɗuɗɗum do huudure petpetel be yahde COVID-19 ɓaandu.

sourceString: The main pathological findings at autopsy are:
targetString: Sappinolji mandolji aranool ha lartol mayde woni:

sourceString: Macroscopy: pleurisy, pericarditis, lung consolidation and pulmonary oedema
targetString: Makroscopy: pleurisy, pericarditis, sattugo fuffu be uppugo fuffu

sourceString: Four types of severity of viral pneumonia can be observed:
targetString: Pneumonia viriis fotti sappina saɗirmaji nay:

sourceString: mild pneumonia: pulmonary oedema, pneumocyte hyperplasia, large atypical pneumocytes, interstitial inflammation with lymphocytic infiltration and multinucleated giant cell formation
targetString: pneumonia je deydey: uppugo fuffu, pneumocyte hyperplasia, maunugo pneumocyteji, huudure interstitial be illol lymphocyte be wondugo cell je ɗon mauni be mari ɓiɓe jur

sourceString: severe pneumonia: diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) with diffuse alveolar exudates.
targetString: pneumonia nyaɗum: diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) be diffuse alveolar exudateji.

sourceString: DAD is the cause of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe hypoxemia.
targetString: DAD is the cause of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe hypoxemia.

sourceString: healing pneumonia: organisation of exudates in alveolar cavities and pulmonary interstitial fibrosis
targetString: pneumonia je hurgotto: kawtirde exudateji ha nder alveolar cavities be pulmonary interstitial fibrosis

sourceString: Blood: disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC); leukoerythroblastic reaction
targetString: Iyam : ɗacce intravascular sankitti (DIC); leukoerythroblastic reaction

sourceString: Preventive measures to reduce the chances of infection include staying at home, avoiding crowded places, washing hands with soap and water often and for at least 20 seconds, practising good respiratory hygiene and avoiding touching the eyes, nose or mouth with unwashed hands.
targetString: Dabareji aynol ngam ustugo sa'iji raɓɓugo nyau larni wondugo ha saare, luttugo kawtirde ummatore, lallugo juɗe be sabulu be ndiyam ha wakati fu ha nder sekonji 20 pettum man, laɓɓinugo lawol pofɗe be aynol tato on memma gite, kine mala hunduko be juɗe je lallay.

sourceString: The CDC recommends covering the mouth and nose with a tissue when coughing or sneezing and recommends using the inside of the elbow if no tissue is available.
targetString: CDC ɗon feela suddugo hunduko be kine to a ɗon sonda mala ɓislugo e ɗon feela bo'o nder jokke jungo moɗon to wala leepol.

sourceString: Proper hand hygiene after any cough or sneeze is encouraged.
targetString: Lallugo juɗe ha ɓawo sondaru mala ɓislol feelama.

sourceString: The CDC has recommended the use of cloth face coverings in public settings, in part to limit transmission by asymptomatic individuals.Social distancing strategies aim to reduce contact of infected persons with large groups by closing schools and workplaces, restricting travel and cancelling large public gatherings.
targetString: CDC feeli ɓornugo limse suddugo yeeso ha wakkere ummatore, ngam ustugo raɓɓol gal yimɓe je sappinata mandolji tawon. Dabareji dayol be ummatore yiɗi ustugo ngidol be yimɓe je ɗon mari nyau ha nder wakkareji je yimɓe ɗuɗɗi ha ton gal maɓɓugo cuuɗi jaangirde be baabe kugal, ustugo jaahangalji be haɗɗugo mofturdeji ummatore.

sourceString: Distancing guidelines also include that people stay at least 6 feet (1.8 m) apart.
targetString: Dabareji dayol larni bo'o wondugo ha pettum man kosɗe 6 (1.8 m) be goɗɗo.

sourceString: There is no medication known to be effective at preventing COVID-19.As a vaccine is not expected until 2021 at the earliest, a key part of managing COVID-19 is trying to decrease the epidemic peak, known as "flattening the curve".
targetString: Wala lekki je ɗon aandi be fakatre ngam aynol nyau COVID-19. Ngam baatal footay wanga hiddeko 2021 ha pettum man, dabare aynugo do COVID-19 lati ustugo yahde nyau, je ɗon aandi bana "jippinugo yahde".

sourceString: The CDC also recommends that individuals wash hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after going to the toilet or when hands are visibly dirty, before eating and after blowing one's nose, coughing or sneezing.
targetString: CDC feeli bo'o yimɓe lalla juɗe maɓɓe ha wakati fu be sabulu be ndiyam nder sekonji 20 pettum man, ɓurna bo'o to a yeehi ha gaɗɗa mala to bana juɗe ɗon mari cuddi, hiddeko nyammugo e ha ɓawo fuffugo kine, sondugo mala ɓislugo.

sourceString: It further recommends using an alcohol-based hand sanitiser with at least 60% alcohol, but only when soap and water are not readily available.For areas where commercial hand sanitisers are not readily available, the WHO provides two formulations for local production.
targetString: O ɗon feela bo'o huwugo be kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe je mari alkol pettum man 60%, amma sey sna to sabulu be ndiyam wala. Ha wakkereji je wala sippol kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe, WHO ɗon hokka mon daɓare waɗugo ɗum be hoore moɗon.

sourceString: In these formulations, the antimicrobial activity arises from ethanol or isopropanol.
targetString: Ha nder laahalji ndu, kugal mbardol gilɗiji ndu wangi gal ethanol mala isopropanol.

sourceString: Hydrogen peroxide is used to help eliminate bacterial spores in the alcohol; it is "not an active substance for hand antisepsis".
targetString: Hydrogen peroxide naffan ngam nattinugo bakteriyaji ha nder alkol; latay "kuje je wondi ngam laɓɓinugo juɗe".

sourceString: Glycerol is added as a humectant.
targetString: Glycerol ɗon ɓesdi bana kuje sofnol.

sourceString: People are managed with supportive care, which may include fluid therapy, oxygen support, and supporting other affected vital organs.
targetString: Yimɓe hokkama suklare ngam fadol, je footi larna hurgol be njaaram, wallende be heendu, be wallugo kujeji ɓaandu feere je ɗon kanduɗum.

sourceString: The CDC recommends that those who suspect they carry the virus wear a simple face mask.
targetString: CDC ɗon feela yo'o ɓe'en je tammi roondugo viriis ɓoorna mask suudugo yeeso.

sourceString: Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) has been used to address the issue of respiratory failure, but its benefits are still under consideration.
targetString: Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) naffiki no ngam hurgugo sababu pofɗe, amma ribaji maɗa ɗon do lartol ha jonta.

sourceString: Personal hygiene and a healthy lifestyle and diet have been recommended to improve immunity.
targetString: Laɓɓinol ɓaandu be jonde e nyamɗe boɗɗe feelama ngam ɓesdugo fadol.

sourceString: Supportive treatments may be useful in those with mild symptoms at the early stage of infection.The WHO and Chinese National Health Commission have published recommendations for taking care of people who are hospitalised with COVID-19.
targetString: Hurgolji walllende footi naffa be maandolji je nyaɗay ha fuɗɗam nyau. WHO be Chinese National Health Commission wangini feeloji ngam suklugo do yimɓe je ɗon woni ha nder suudu lekki je mari COVID-19.

sourceString: Intensivists and pulmonologists in the U.S. have compiled treatment recommendations from various agencies into a free resource, the IBCC.
targetString: Huwooɓe be jaawal mala ɗon sukla do fuffu ha Lesɗe America wurtini feeloji ha geeɓeji jur ngam wallende meere, IBCC.

sourceString: As of April 2020, there is no specific treatment for COVID-19.
targetString: Ha Aviiril 2020, woda hurgol COVID-19 je kkanduɗum.

sourceString: For symptoms, some medical professionals recommend paracetamol (acetaminophen) over ibuprofen for first-line use.
targetString: Ko larni matinolji, huwooɓe do jam ɓaandu feeli paracetamol (acetaminophen) do ibuprofen ha nyauɓe.

sourceString: Precautions must be taken to minimise the risk of virus transmission, especially in healthcare settings when performing procedures that can generate aerosols, such as intubation or hand ventilation.
targetString: Sey huwa be hakkika ngam ustugo sababu raɓɓugo gilɗi, ɓurna fu ha nder wakkerji jam ɓaanɗu ha yakke waɗugo laahalji je footi footi wurtina pofɗe, bana nastinol kuje ha nder daande mala fartol hendu be jungo.

sourceString: For healthcare professionals caring for people with COVID-19, the CDC recommends placing the person in an Airborne Infection Isolation Room (AIIR) in addition to using standard precautions, contact precautions and airborne precautions.The CDC outlines the guidelines for the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) during the pandemic.
targetString: Ha huwoɓe je sulata do jam ɓaandu yimɓ be COVID-19, CDC ɗon feela wattugo goɗɗo man ha nder Airborne Infection Isolation Room (AIIR) HA ɓesdugo do kugal be hakkika. CDC ɗon wangini dabareji ngam fadol hoore mum (PPE) ha wakati nyau duniyaru ndu.

sourceString: The recommended gear is: PPE gown, respirator or facemask, eye protection, and medical gloves.When available, respirators (instead of facemasks) are preferred.
targetString: Kujeji je ɗon feeli ngam ɓornugo: ngapaleewol PPE, ordo fuffugo mala mask suddugo yeeso, kuje fadugo gite, be kujeji suddugo juɗe. To wodi, ordo pofɗe (do mask sudugo yeeso) ɓuri naffugo.

sourceString: N95 respirators are approved for industrial settings but the FDA has authorised the masks for use under an Emergency Use Authorisation (EUA).
targetString: Ordoji fuffugo N95 jarfama ngam huwugo ha wakkereji tagle kujeji amma FDA jarfi maskji ndu nder kugal Emergency Use Authorisation (EUA).

sourceString: They are designed to protect from airborne particles like dust but effectiveness against a specific biological agent is not guaranteed for off-label uses.
targetString: Kugal maɓɓe lati fadugo ngam kujeji je hendu roondi bana coolaaje amma naffuda man ngam gilɗi je ɗon aandin footay hokka jabbuye je fakatre.

sourceString: When masks are not available, the CDC recommends using face shields or, as a last resort, homemade masks.
targetString: To maskji wala, CDC ɗon feela ɓornugo kuje fadugo yeeso mala, bana dabare je ragare, maskji je waɗama ha saare.

sourceString: Most cases of COVID-19 are not severe enough to require mechanical ventilation or alternatives, but a percentage of cases are.
targetString: Nyauɓe COVID-19 ɓurna fu ɗon emma fartol hendu be ordo mala dabare feere, NS

sourceString: The type of respiratory support for individuals with COVID-19 related respiratory failure is being actively studied for people in hospital, with some evidence that intubation can be avoided with a high flow nasal cannula or bi-level positive airway pressure.
targetString: Irin wallende pofɗe ha yimɓe je mari nyau COVID-19 be saɗirma nder pofɗe ɗon do ekkitol ngam yimɓe je ɗon woni ha suudu lekki, be sappinol je footi acca nastirde kuje fuffugo ha nder daande be illam kine je nyaɗum be saɗirmaji pofɗe.

sourceString: Whether either of these two leads to the same benefit for people who are critically ill is not known.
targetString: To ɗiɗi fu ɗon yara ha ribaji fu je naffata yimɓe je ɗon mari nyau man maasin wala fammugo tawon.

sourceString: Some doctors prefer staying with invasive mechanical ventilation when available because this technique limits the spread of aerosol particles compared to a high flow nasal cannula.Severe cases are most common in older adults (those older than 60 years, and especially those older than 80 years).
targetString: Lekkitoɓe feere yardi wondugo be fartol hendu be ordo to wodi ngam dabare ndu ɗon usta sankittol kujeji je heendu footi horta to foondi be illam kine je nyaɗum. Nyau ndu ɓuri nyaɗugo ha ndotti'en (ɓe'en je ɓuri duɓɓi 60, ɓurna fu ɓe'en je ɓuri duɓɓi 80).

sourceString: Many developed countries do not have enough hospital beds per capita, which limits a health system's capacity to handle a sudden spike in the number of COVID-19 cases severe enough to require hospitalisation.
targetString: Lesɗe je ɗon mari aandal e risku ɗuɗɗum maray leesoji suudi lekki je yimbe fu, kanjuum wadi footay yimɓe fu heɓɓa nyambitol to limgal nyauɓe COVID-19 je mari haaje wondugo ha suudu lekki wa'i.

sourceString: One study in China found 5% were admitted to intensive care units, 2.3% needed mechanical support of ventilation, and 1.4% died.
targetString: Ekkitol feere ha Cayna sappini yo'o 5% neldotto ha geeɓe suklare nyaɗum, 2.3% mari no haaje fartol heendu gal ordo, be 1.4% maynama.

sourceString: In China, approximately 30% of people in hospital with COVID-19 are eventually admitted to ICU.
targetString: Ha Cayna, ɓadi 30% yimɓe ha suudu lekki be COVID-19 neldotto ha ICU.

sourceString: Mechanical ventilation becomes more complex as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) develops in COVID-19 and oxygenation becomes increasingly difficult.
targetString: Fartol gal ordo latan caɗɗungel masitin to saɗirma nder pofɗe ɗon fuɗɗa (ARDS) ha COVID-19 be hendu je ɗon lata caɗɗum masitin.

sourceString: Ventilators capable of pressure control modes and high PEEP are needed to maximise oxygen delivery while minimising the risk of ventilator-associated lung injury and pneumothorax.
targetString: Ordoji waɗugo heendu je footi ayna harloji be PEEP je mauni naffan ngam ɓesdugo heendu ha yakke ustugo sababu huudure do fuffu be pneunomothorax ngam ordo fartugo hendu.

sourceString: High PEEP may not be available on older ventilators.
targetString: PEEP footi tawakke ha nder ordoji pofɗe je aran.

sourceString: Research into potential treatments started in January 2020, and several antiviral drugs are in clinical trials.
targetString: Teffol ngam tammunde hurgolji fuɗɗi ha Zaanviye 2020 be lekki mbardugo viriisji jur ɗon do foondolji ha suudu lekki.

sourceString: Remdesivir appears to be the most promising.
targetString: Remdesivir lati bana ɓuri naffugo.

sourceString: Although new medications may take until 2021 to develop, several of the medications being tested are already approved for other uses or are already in advanced testing.
targetString: Ko to lekki keese footi yotta ha 2021 hiddeko wurtugo, lekki jur ɗon do lartol e lati jaɓɓama ngam kugal feere mala ɗon do lartol je dayɗum timmi.

sourceString: Antiviral medication may be tried in people with severe disease.
targetString: Lekki mbardugo viriis footi foondotto ha yimɓe be nyau nyaɗum.

sourceString: The WHO recommended volunteers take part in trials of the effectiveness and safety of potential treatments.The FDA has granted temporary authorisation to convalescent plasma as an experimental treatment in cases where the person's life is seriously or immediately threatened.
targetString: WHO feeli foondooɓe wonda ha nder lartol naffuda be jam hurgolji je footi yotta. FDA hokki jarfuye be wakati ha neebam iyam bana hurgol foondol ha nyauɓe je nyau maɓɓe ɓuri nyaɗugo.

sourceString: It has not undergone the clinical studies needed to show it is safe and effective for the disease.
targetString: Sallinay ekkitolji suudu lekki je aandin no  ngam sappinugo lati kanduɗum e wodi naffitirki ngam nyau.

sourceString: In February 2020, China launched a mobile app to deal with the disease outbreak.
targetString: Ha Feviriye 2020, Cayna wurtini applikasion feere je aynata sankittol nyau ndu.

sourceString: Users are asked to enter their name and ID number.
targetString: Howooɓe be majuum emmotto ngam nastinugo lamba mandirɗum maɓɓe.

sourceString: The app is able to detect 'close contact' using surveillance data and therefore a potential risk of infection.
targetString: Applikasion ndu footi maanda "ngidol je ɓaditi" gal huwidugo be matinolji aynol e nden kadi bana sababu raɓɓugo nyau.

sourceString: Every user can also check the status of three other users.
targetString: Kala huwoowo be majuum footi larta wonde yimɓe feere tati je ɗon mari.

sourceString: If a potential risk is detected, the app not only recommends self-quarantine, it also alerts local health officials.Big data analytics on cellphone data, facial recognition technology, mobile phone tracking and artificial intelligence are used to track infected people and people whom they contacted in South Korea, Taiwan and Singapore.
targetString: To wodi sababu feere ɗon tawi, applikasion ndu feelatta mon wondugo seera tan, amma matinan bo'o huwooɓe do jam ɓaandu wakkere ndu. Matinolji lartol ɗuɗɗum do matinolji telefon, dabare maandirɗum yeeso, tokkitol wakkere  woonde be aandal ordo naffan ngam tawittugo yimɓe je ɗon mari nyau be yimɓe be yimɓe je ɓe ngidi be maɓɓe ha South Koorea, Taiwan be Singapore.

sourceString: In March 2020, the Israeli government enabled security agencies to track mobile phone data of people supposed to have coronavirus.
targetString: Ha Maars 2020, ngomna Israyila hokki jarfuye ha geeɓeji jam ngam tokkitugo mandolji telefon yimɓe bana mari nyau koronaviriis.

sourceString: The measure was taken to enforce quarantine and protect those who may come into contact with infected citizens.
targetString: Dabare ndu hoosama ngam aynugo do wondugo ha seera be fadugo ɓe'en je footi ngida be yimɓe je ɗon mari nyau.

sourceString: Also in March 2020, Deutsche Telekom shared aggregated phone location data with the German federal government agency, Robert Koch Institute, in order to research and prevent the spread of the virus.
targetString: Fahin ha Maars 2020, Deutsche Telekon sendi matinolji mandol wakkereji telefon je ɗon hawti be geeɓe ngomna lesdi Jaamani, Robert Koch Institute, ngam teffugo e aynugo sankittol viriis.

sourceString: Russia deployed facial recognition technology to detect quarantine breakers.
targetString: Russiya wangini dabare maandirɗum yeeso ngam maandugu yimɓe je yiɗa wondugo ha seera.

sourceString: Italian regional health commissioner Giulio Gallera said he has been informed by mobile phone operators that "40% of people are continuing to move around anyway".
targetString: Arduɗo do jam ɓaandu lesdi Italy Giulio Gallera wi'i arduɓe telefon matini mo'o yo'o "40% yimɓe ɗon tokkita tarugo".

sourceString: German government conducted a 48 hours weekend hackathon with more than 42.000 participants.
targetString: Ngomna Jaamani sallini ekkitol gal yurnol matinolji ha nder njamɗe be yimɓe 42000.

sourceString: Also the president of Estonia, Kersti Kaljulaid, made a global call for creative solutions against the spread of coronavirus.
targetString: Fahin, Jagorɗo Estoniya, Kersti Kaljulaid, ewni yimɓe jur ngam dabareji ummatore nder aandalji kanduɗum do sankittol koronaviriis.

sourceString: Individuals may experience distress from quarantine, travel restrictions, side effects of treatment or fear of the infection itself.
targetString: Yimɓe footi heɓɓa larula ngam wondugo ha seera, haɗɗol jaahangalji, sababuji hurgol  be hulol nyau man.

sourceString: BBC quoted Rory O'Connor in saying, "Increased social isolation, loneliness, health anxiety, stress and an economic downturn are a perfect storm to harm people's mental health and wellbeing."
targetString: BBC lorniti ko Rory O'Connor be wi'ugo, "Wondugo ha seera ummatore je ɓuri, wondugo feerejo, nummol do jam ɓaandu, tampere be ustol mardi lati bana dulluru ngam gaanyugo jam hakkilo e jam woore yimɓe".

sourceString: The disease may take a mild course with few or no symptoms, resembling other common upper respiratory diseases such as the common cold.
targetString: Nyau ndu footi yocca yahde deydey be mandolji seeɗa mala woda, je ɗon naandi irin nyauji lawol pofɗe je do bana ndamba meere.

sourceString: Mild cases typically recover within two weeks, while those with severe or critical diseases may take three to six weeks to recover.
targetString: Nyauɓe je ɗon mari nyau deydey tan ɓurna fu nyamɓittan ha nder asawere ɗiɗi, ɓe'en je mari nyau je nyaɗi mala je ɓuri nyauɗugo footi hoosa asaweji tati ha joowey e go'o ha nyamɓitta.

sourceString: Pregnant women may be at higher risk for severe infection with COVID-19 based on data from other similar viruses, like SARS and MERS, but data for COVID-19 is lacking.In some people, COVID-19 may affect the lungs causing pneumonia.
targetString: Rewɓe be reedu footi mara sababuji ɓuri nyaɗugo ngam COVID-19 do mandolji je tawama do irin koronaviriis ndu, bana SARS be MERS, amma matinolji do  COVID-19 woda. Ha yimɓe feere, COVID-19 footi memma fuffu e hokka pneumonia.

sourceString: In those most severely affected, COVID-19 may rapidly progress to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) causing respiratory failure, septic shock or multi-organ failure.
targetString: Ha ɓe'en je nyau ɗon torra masin, COVID-19 footi yotta ha nyau pofɗe je deydey (ARDS) ko ɗon wada saɗirma nder pofɗe, duwinol mala nyau kujeji feere nder ɓaandu.

sourceString: Complications associated with COVID-19 include sepsis, abnormal clotting and damage to the heart, kidneys and liver.
targetString: Saɗirmaji be COVID-19 larni nawnol ɓaandu, ɗajjugo mala nawnugo bernde, ɓooye be hengre.

sourceString: Clotting abnormalities, specifically an increase in prothrombin time, have been described in 6% of those admitted to hospital with COVID-19, while abnormal kidney function is seen in 4% of this group.
targetString: Ɗajjol iyam je wonay be lawol, be ɓesdare wakati prothrombin, sappinotto ha 6% ɓe'en je neldama ha suudu lekki be COVID-19, be 4% ɓooye je huwata boɗɗum ha nder geeɓe.

sourceString: Approximately 20-30% of people who present with COVID-19 demonstrate elevated liver enzymes (transaminases).
targetString: Ɓadi 20-30% yimɓe je mari COVID-19 ɗon sappina neebam hengre (transaminaseji) mauni.

sourceString: According to the same report, the median time between onset of symptoms and death was ten days, with five being spent hospitalised.
targetString: Ha limte batakkewol ndu, wakati cakkare digga fuɗɗam mandolji ha wade woni no balɗe sappo, be joowey wondi ha suudu lekki.

sourceString: However, patients transferred to an ICU had a median time of seven days between hospitalisation and death.
targetString: Ama, nyauɓe je ɓe neldi ha nder ICU ɗon mari wakati balɓe joowey e ɗiɗi ha kunde wondugo ha suudu lekki be mayde.

sourceString: In a study of early cases, the median time from exhibiting initial symptoms to death was 14 days, with a full range of six to 41 days.
targetString: Ha nder ekkitol arandere nyauɓe, wakati cakkare diga fuɗɗam mandolji ha mayde lati no balɗe 14, be balɗe yahan diga joowey e go'o ha 41.

sourceString: In a study by the National Health Commission (NHC) of China, men had a death rate of 2.8% while women had a death rate of 1.7%.
targetString: Ha nder ekkitol National Health Commission (NHC) Cayna, worɓe mari no limtol mayde 2.8% e rewɓe mari no limtol wade 1.7%.

sourceString: Histopathological examinations of post-mortem lung samples show diffuse alveolar damage with cellular fibromyxoid exudates in both lungs.
targetString: Lartolji tariya nyau ndu ha nder leeku fuffu mayɗo ɗon sappina diffuse alveolar damage be cellular fibromyxoid exudateji ha nder fuffu ɗiɗi fu.

sourceString: Viral cytopathic changes were observed in the pneumocytes.
targetString: Saanjolji viriis ha nder cellji tawama ha nder pneumocyteji.

sourceString: The lung picture resembled acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
targetString: Foto fuffu naandi no nyau saɗirma pofɗe (ARDS).

sourceString: In 11.8% of the deaths reported by the National Health Commission of China, heart damage was noted by elevated levels of troponin or cardiac arrest.
targetString: Ha kunde 11.8% mayɓe je ɗon matini gal National Health Commission Cayna, memmol ɓernde matinotto be limtol tropinin mala darnol ɓernde.

sourceString: According to March data from the United States, 89% of those hospitalised had preexisting conditions.Availability of medical resources and the socioeconomics of a region may also affect mortality.
targetString: Ha sappinol matinolji Maars ha Lesɗe America, 89% je ɓe'en je wondi ha suudu lekki e mari saɗirmaji feere. Wondugo dabareji jam ɓaandu jonde ummatore be mardi wakkere ndu footi memma limtol mayde

sourceString: Estimates of the mortality from the condition vary because of those regional differences, but also because of methodological difficulties.
targetString: Limtol mayde ngam saɗirma ɗon saanja ngam feeretirolji wekkereji ndu, amma bo'o ngam larulaji yahde laahal.

sourceString: The under-counting of mild cases can cause the mortality rate to be overestimated.
targetString: Limgal nyauɓe je maray larula jur footi ɓesda limtol mayde.

sourceString: However, the fact that deaths are the result of cases contracted in the past can mean the current mortality rate is underestimated.
targetString: Amma, ko je mayde lati sappinol nyauɓe je nangi nyau ndu ara footi wi'a yo'o limtol mayde jonta ɗon lessi.

sourceString: Smokers were 1.4 times more likely to have severe symptoms of COVID-19 and approximately 2.4 times more likely to require intensive care or die compared to non-smokers.Concerns have been raised about long-term sequelae of the disease.
targetString: Foɗɗooɓe woni no bana ɗon sappina mandolji nyau je nyaɗum ha COVID-19 nde 1.4 be ɓadi nde 2.4 je bana ɓuri marugo haaje suklare feere mala maya to foondi be ɓe'en je wala foɗɗugo. Wodi larulaji je wangi ngam ko nyau man accatta ha ɓawo to hurgi.

sourceString: The Hong Kong Hospital Authority found a drop of 20% to 30% in lung capacity in some people who recovered from the disease, and lung scans suggested organ damage.
targetString: Hong Kong Hospital Authority sappini jippol 20% be 30% ha nder sembe fuffu ha yimɓe je nyamɓitti nder nyau ndu, be lartol fuffu je ɗon no holla sampittol.

sourceString: This may also lead to post-intensive care syndrome following recovery.
targetString: Ndu footi yara ha nyau suklugo do jam ɓandu ha ɓawo nyamɓittol.

sourceString: As of March 2020, it was unknown if past infection provides effective and long-term immunity in people who recover from the disease.
targetString: Ha Maars 2020, yimɓe aanda no to nyau je sallingo ɗon hokka fadol ha yimɓe je yamɓittama.

sourceString: Immunity is seen as likely, based on the behaviour of other coronaviruses, but cases in which recovery from COVID-19 have been followed by positive tests for coronavirus at a later date have been reported.
targetString: Fadol lati bana footi, do gikku koronaviriisji feere, amma nyauɓe je nyamɓitti ha COVID-19 tokkitotto be lartolji je ɗon sappina o ɗon mari nyau woni.

sourceString: These cases are believed to be worsening of a lingering infection rather than re-infection.
targetString: Irin hurgolji ndu tammi bana nyau feere je ɗon ɗaayi do wonugo raɓɓol keese.

sourceString: The virus is thought to be natural and have an animal origin, through spillover infection.
targetString: Viriis ndu ɗon tammi bana woni ha ladde e wangi gal daabaji, gal nyau je hebbi timmi.

sourceString: The actual origin is unknown, but by December 2019 the spread of infection was almost entirely driven by human-to-human transmission.
targetString: En aanda gal toy wanngi, amma gal lewru Desambre 2019 yaajugo nyau man salli ɓurna yimɓe, oya ha oya.

sourceString: A study of the first 41 cases of confirmed COVID-19, published in January 2020 in The Lancet, revealed the earliest date of onset of symptoms as 1 December 2019.
targetString: Jaangirde arandere nyauɓe 41 je ɗon aandi mari COVID-19, je wurti ha Zaanviye 2020 ha Lancet, sappini wakati je mandolji je ɓuri wangugo be laugel ha 1 Desambre 2019.

sourceString: Official publications from the WHO reported the earliest onset of symptoms as 8 December 2019.
targetString: Sappinolji WHO sappini arandere fuɗɗam wangol mandolji ha 8 Desambre 2019.

sourceString: Several measures are commonly used to quantify mortality.
targetString: Dabareji ɗuɗɗum ɗon ɓurna naffa ngam limtol mayɓe.

sourceString: These numbers vary by region and over time and are influenced by the volume of testing, healthcare system quality, treatment options, time since initial outbreak and population characteristics such as age, sex and overall health.
targetString: Limtolji ndu ɗon saanja be wakare e be wakati e memmotto gal lartolji, daraja dabare jam ɓaandu, suɓɓolji hurgol, wakati diga fuɗɗam aranool wangirde nyau be gikku ummatore bana duɓɓi, baadal be jam ɓaandu fu.

sourceString: In late 2019, WHO assigned the emergency ICD-10 disease codes U07.1 for deaths from lab-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection and U07.2 for deaths from clinically or epidemiologically diagnosed COVID-19 without lab-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection.The death-to-case ratio reflects the number of deaths divided by the number of diagnosed cases within a given time interval.
targetString: Ha ragare 2019, WHO hokki jaawal lamba nyau ICD-10 U07.1 ngam mayde diga fammugo nyau SARS-CoV-2 ha nder suudu lartol be U07.1 ngam mayde je tawake ha suudu lekki mala gal nyau COVID-19 bila SARS-CoV-2 je nastay ha suudu lekki. Limtol nyauɓe ha kunde maybe larni limgal yimɓe je maynama sendugo man be limgal yimɓe je ɗon mari nyau man ha nder wakati je ɗon aandin.

sourceString: Based on Johns Hopkins University statistics, the global death-to-case ratio is 6.9% (153,822/2,240,191) as of 17 April 2020.
targetString: Wondugo do sappinolji Johns Hopkins University, limtol wade do nyauɗo woni 6.9% (153,822/2,240,191) diga 17 Aviiril 2020.

sourceString: The number varies by region.Other measures include the case fatality rate (CFR), which reflects the percent of diagnosed individuals who die from a disease, and the infection fatality rate (IFR), which reflects the percent of infected individuals (diagnosed and undiagnosed) who die from a disease.
targetString: Limgal ɗon saanja be wakkere. Dabareji feere larni limtol mayde (CFR), je ɗon sappina limgal yimɓe je mari no nyau e mayi, be limtol raɓɓol (IFR), je ɗon holla limtol yimɓe (je larti be lartay) je mayi ngam nyau feere.

sourceString: These statistics are not time bound and follow a specific population from infection through case resolution.
targetString: Sappinolji ndu larnay wakati e ɗon tokkita ummatore feerejo ngam nyau gal hurgol nyau.

sourceString: While not all infected people develop antibodies, the presence of antibodies may provide information about how many people have been infected.
targetString: Ko to na kala moy fu footi ummina kujeji fadugo ɓaandu, wondugo maɓɓe footi hokka matinolji do noy yimɓe jur raɓɓi nyau ndu.

sourceString: In the epicentre of the outbreak in Italy, Castiglione d'Adda, a small village of 4600, 80 (1.7%) are already dead.
targetString: Ha nder cakkare nyau ha Italy, Castiglione d'Adda, wuro pamarron be yimɓe 4600, be 80 (1.7%) maynama timmi.

sourceString: In Gangelt, the disease was spread by Carnival festivals, and spread to younger people, causing a relatively lower mortality, and not all COVID-19 deaths may have been formally classified as such.
targetString: Ha Gangelt, nyau sankitti gal juldeji Carnival, e raɓɓi ummatore sukkaɓe, be limtol mayde seeɗa tan, e na kala mayɗo ngam COVID-19 nastan ha nder geeɓe ndu.

sourceString: Furthermore, the German health system has not been overwhelmed.
targetString: Fahin bo'o, dabare jam ɓaandu Jaamani ɓuray tawon.

sourceString: In the Netherlands, about 3% may have antibodies, as assessed from blood donors.
targetString: Ha Netherlands, ɓadi 3% footi mara fadooɓe ɓaandu, bana ko ɗo sappina iyam hokkooɓe.

sourceString: 69 (0.004% of the population) have been confirmed to have died from COVID-19.
targetString: 69 (0.004% ummatore) aandi bana mayi ngam COVID-19.

sourceString: The impact of the pandemic and its mortality rate are different for men and women.
targetString: Sembe nyau be.limtol mayde ɗon feere-feere ha kunde worɓe be rewɓe

sourceString: Mortality is higher in men in studies conducted in China and Italy.
targetString: Limtol mayde ɓuri maunugo ha worɓe ha nder ekkitolji je salli ha Cayna be Italy.
